levels.label: entry
levels.description: Counting in 4s from zero using concrete groups of 4 objects, supported by a number line with multiples of 4 highlighted.
levels.example_task: Place 4 cubes, then 4 more, then 4 more. Count the total each time: 4, 8, 12. Continue the pattern to 40.
common_errors: Counting in 2s instead of 4s (4, 6, 8, 10...)
Losing track and reverting to counting in 1s after 20

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Counting forwards and backwards in 4s from zero without concrete support, using a number line or hundred square if needed.
levels.example_task: Count backwards in 4s from 40 to 0.
common_errors: Counting backwards in 1s instead of 4s (40, 39, 38...)
Skipping a number in the sequence (40, 36, 28...)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Counting in 4s from any given multiple of 4, forwards and backwards, without support.
levels.example_task: Start at 24. Count on in 4s until you reach 48.
common_errors: Needing to restart from 0 to reach the starting point before continuing
Stumbling at decade boundaries (e.g. 28 to 32, crossing from twenties to thirties)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using the relationship between counting in 2s and counting in 4s to explain patterns and answer reasoning questions.
levels.example_task: Explain why every multiple of 4 is also a multiple of 2. Give three examples.
levels.example_response: Every multiple of 4 is a multiple of 2 because 4 = 2 x 2, so counting in 4s is like counting in 2s twice. Examples: 12 is 4 x 3 and 2 x 6; 20 is 4 x 5 and 2 x 10; 36 is 4 x 9 and 2 x 18.
common_errors: Giving examples but no explanation of the doubling relationship
Confusing 'multiple of 4' with 'multiple of 2' and claiming all even numbers are multiples of 4

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Counting in 8s from zero using groups of 8 objects (e.g. spider legs), supported by a number line.
levels.example_task: Use cubes in groups of 8. Count the total as you add each group: 8, 16, 24. Continue to 80.
common_errors: Losing count after 32 and guessing (e.g. 32, 38, 44...)
Counting in 4s instead of 8s

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Counting forwards and backwards in 8s from zero using the doubling connection to the 4 times table as a strategy.
levels.example_task: Count backwards in 8s from 80 to 0.
common_errors: Errors at transitions: 72 to 64 (saying 62 or 66)
Reverting to counting back in ones from 56 onwards

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Counting in 8s from any given multiple of 8, forwards and backwards, with fluency.
levels.example_task: Start at 32. Count on in 8s to 72.
common_errors: Needing to recite the whole sequence from 8 before continuing from 32
Saying 32, 40, 46 instead of 32, 40, 48 (adding 6 instead of 8)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining the doubling chain from 2s to 4s to 8s and using it to derive or check multiples of 8.
levels.example_task: The 4 times table says 4 x 7 = 28. Use this to work out 8 x 7. Explain your method.
levels.example_response: 8 x 7 = double 4 x 7 = double 28 = 56. This works because 8 is double 4, so every answer in the 8 times table is double the matching answer in the 4 times table.
common_errors: Doubling incorrectly (double 28 = 46 instead of 56)
Not being able to explain why doubling works, only knowing the procedure

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Counting in 50s from zero using 50p coins or a number line marked in 50s.
levels.example_task: Put 50p coins in a line, one at a time. Count the total as you go: 50, 100, 150... Continue to 500.
common_errors: Adding 5 instead of 50 (50, 55, 60...)
Getting confused at the hundreds boundary (250, 300, 310 instead of 350)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Counting forwards and backwards in 50s, including crossing hundreds boundaries, using a number line if needed.
levels.example_task: Count backwards in 50s from 400 to 100.
common_errors: Subtracting 50 inconsistently (400, 350, 300, 260...)
Skipping a hundreds boundary (400, 350, 250...)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Counting in 50s from any given multiple of 50, in both directions, without support.
levels.example_task: Start at 350. Count on in 50s to 700.
common_errors: Hesitating or making errors at boundaries (350, 400, 440 instead of 450)
Adding 100 instead of 50 at some points

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Counting in 100s from zero using Dienes hundreds flats, placing one flat at a time and counting the total.
levels.example_task: Place hundreds flats one at a time. Count: 100, 200, 300... Continue to 1000.
common_errors: Saying 'ten hundred' instead of 'one thousand' for 1000
Counting in 10s instead of 100s

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Counting forwards and backwards in 100s from zero without concrete support.
levels.example_task: Count backwards in 100s from 1000 to 0.
common_errors: Hesitating or stopping at 100 rather than reaching 0
Counting in 10s instead of 100s when going backwards

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Counting in 100s from any given multiple of 100, in both directions, fluently.
levels.example_task: Start at 400. Count on in 100s to 900.
common_errors: Adding 10 instead of 100 (400, 410, 420...)
Needing to start from 0 each time rather than from the given number

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding 10 more or 10 less using Dienes blocks for three-digit numbers that do not cross a tens boundary.
levels.example_task: Show 253 with Dienes blocks. Add one tens rod. What number do you have now?
levels.example_response: 263. The tens changed from 5 to 6 but the hundreds (2) and ones (3) stayed the same.
common_errors: Changing the ones digit instead of the tens digit (253 + 10 = 254)
Changing the hundreds digit instead of the tens digit (253 + 10 = 353)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Finding 10 more or less for three-digit numbers without concrete support, including cases where the tens digit is 0 or 9.
levels.example_task: What is 10 less than 305?
levels.example_response: 295. The tens digit goes from 0 to 9 and the hundreds digit decreases by 1 (from 3 to 2).
common_errors: Saying 10 less than 305 is 205 (subtracting 100 instead of 10)
Saying 10 less than 305 is 395 (incorrectly borrowing from the ones)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Rapid recall of 10 more and 10 less for any three-digit number, including boundary cases, without support.
levels.example_task: What is 10 more than 496? What is 10 less than 700?
levels.example_response: 10 more than 496 is 506. 10 less than 700 is 690.
common_errors: Saying 10 more than 496 is 4106 (concatenating digits instead of carrying)
Saying 10 less than 700 is 600 (subtracting 100 instead of 10)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining what happens to the place value columns when finding 10 more or less at boundary cases.
levels.example_task: Explain why finding 10 more than 390 changes two digits. What happens to the hundreds and tens?
levels.example_response: 390 + 10 = 400. The tens go from 9 to 0 because 9 tens + 1 ten = 10 tens, which equals 1 hundred. So the hundreds go up by 1 (from 3 to 4) and the tens become 0.
common_errors: Being unable to explain the regrouping, only knowing the answer
Saying 'the 9 turns into 10' without linking this to the hundreds column

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding 100 more or 100 less using Dienes hundreds flats for three-digit numbers.
levels.example_task: Show 347 with Dienes blocks. Add one hundreds flat. What number do you have now?
levels.example_response: 447. Only the hundreds digit changed (from 3 to 4). The tens (4) and ones (7) stayed the same.
common_errors: Changing the tens digit instead of the hundreds (347 + 100 = 357)
Adding 10 instead of 100 (347 + 100 = 357)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Finding 100 more or less for three-digit numbers without concrete support, including numbers below 200.
levels.example_task: What is 100 less than 150?
common_errors: Saying 100 less than 150 is 140 (subtracting 10 instead of 100)
Being unsure because the result is a two-digit number

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Rapid recall of 100 more and 100 less for any three-digit number, including the 900-to-1000 boundary.
levels.example_task: What is 100 more than 923? What is 100 less than 208?
levels.example_response: 100 more than 923 is 1023. 100 less than 208 is 108.
common_errors: Saying 100 more than 923 is 933 (adding 10 instead of 100)
Being unsure whether 1023 is a valid answer because it has four digits

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Identifying the value of each digit in a three-digit number using Dienes blocks and a place value mat (H T O columns).
levels.example_task: Build 352 with Dienes blocks on a place value mat. How many hundreds, tens and ones are there?
levels.example_response: 3 hundreds, 5 tens, 2 ones. The 3 is worth 300, the 5 is worth 50, and the 2 is worth 2.
common_errors: Saying the 3 is worth 3 rather than 300
Confusing tens and ones columns on the mat

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying the value of each digit using arrow cards or pictorial place value charts, including numbers with zero as a placeholder.
levels.example_task: What is the value of the 0 in 407?
levels.example_response: The 0 means there are no tens. 407 = 400 + 0 + 7.
common_errors: Saying the 0 has no meaning or ignoring it (reading 407 as 47)
Saying the 0 is worth 0 without explaining it means 'zero tens'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Stating the value of any digit in any three-digit number without support, and using this to explain calculations.
levels.example_task: In 763, what is the value of each digit? Use this to explain why 763 = 700 + 60 + 3.
levels.example_response: The 7 is worth 700 because it is in the hundreds column. The 6 is worth 60 because it is in the tens column. The 3 is worth 3 because it is in the ones column. So 763 = 700 + 60 + 3.
common_errors: Adding the digits (7 + 6 + 3 = 16) instead of stating their place values
Mixing up the values (saying the 6 is worth 600 and the 7 is worth 70)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using place value reasoning to answer questions about digit changes and number composition.
levels.example_task: I am thinking of a three-digit number. The hundreds digit is 5. The tens digit is double the ones digit. The number is less than 530. What could the number be?
levels.example_response: The tens digit must be double the ones digit, and the number is less than 530 so the tens digit must be 0, 1 or 2. If tens = 0, ones = 0, the number is 500. If tens = 2, ones = 1, the number is 521. If tens = 4, ones = 2, that gives 542 which is more than 530. So the number is 500 or 521.
common_errors: Not working systematically through the possibilities
Forgetting the constraint that the number must be less than 530

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Standard partitioning of three-digit numbers using Dienes blocks and arrow cards (e.g. 347 = 300 + 40 + 7).
levels.example_task: Use arrow cards to show how 528 can be split into hundreds, tens and ones.
levels.example_response: 528 = 500 + 20 + 8. The arrow cards are 500, 20 and 8.
common_errors: Writing 528 = 5 + 2 + 8 (digit values rather than place values)
Struggling with zero placeholders: partitioning 503 as 500 + 3 but forgetting the 0 tens

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Standard partitioning without concrete support, including numbers with zeros, recorded using addition notation.
levels.example_task: Partition 604 into hundreds, tens and ones.
common_errors: Omitting the zero tens entirely (writing 604 = 600 + 4 only)
Writing 604 = 64 (ignoring the hundreds)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Flexible (non-standard) partitioning of three-digit numbers in multiple ways to support calculation.
levels.example_task: Partition 347 in three different ways.
common_errors: Only knowing standard partitioning and being unable to create alternatives
Creating invalid partitions where the parts do not sum to the original number

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using flexible partitioning strategically to make a specific calculation easier, and explaining why.
levels.example_task: Which partitioning of 347 would help you calculate 347 - 50 mentally? Explain.
levels.example_response: Partition 347 as 350 - 3. Then 350 - 50 = 300, and 300 - 3 = 297. This works because 350 is a near-multiple of 50, making the subtraction easier.
common_errors: Choosing a partitioning that does not help with the calculation
Being unable to explain why one partitioning is more helpful than another

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Comparing two three-digit numbers using Dienes blocks to see which has more hundreds, tens or ones.
levels.example_task: Build 356 and 348 with Dienes blocks. Which number is greater?
levels.example_response: 356 is greater than 348. They both have 3 hundreds, but 356 has 5 tens and 348 only has 4 tens. 356 > 348.
common_errors: Comparing the ones digits only (saying 348 > 356 because 8 > 6)
Saying 'they are the same' because the hundreds are the same

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Comparing two three-digit numbers using place value reasoning and the > < = symbols, without concrete support.
levels.example_task: Put the correct symbol (>, < or =) between these numbers: 465 ___ 456
levels.example_response: 465 > 456. The hundreds are both 4, the tens are 6 and 5, and 6 tens is more than 5 tens.
common_errors: Confusing > and < symbols (writing 465 < 456)
Not checking beyond the first digit that differs

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Ordering a set of up to six three-digit numbers in ascending or descending order, using systematic place value comparison.
levels.example_task: Put these numbers in order from smallest to largest: 503, 350, 530, 305, 535, 353
common_errors: Ordering by the first digit only without comparing subsequent digits when hundreds are equal
Confusing ascending and descending order

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Solving reasoning problems that require comparing and ordering with missing digits or constraints.
levels.example_task: I have three numbers: 4_6, 46_, and _56. The missing digits are 3, 5, and 7. Place them so the three numbers are in ascending order.
levels.example_response: Put 3 in the first gap: 436. Put 5 in the third gap: 556. Put 7 in the second gap: 467. Check ascending order: 436, 467, 556. Yes, that works.
common_errors: Placing digits randomly without checking the resulting order
Not considering all possible arrangements before settling on one

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Estimating the position of a number on a number line marked at 0 and 1000, using the halfway point (500) as a benchmark.
levels.example_task: Here is a number line from 0 to 1000. An arrow points to a position. Is it closer to 0, 500 or 1000?
levels.example_response: The arrow is past halfway, closer to 1000. I estimate about 750.
common_errors: Guessing with no reasoning (saying 'about 200' for a position clearly past halfway)
Treating estimation as exact counting

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Estimating positions on number lines with more benchmark points (0, 250, 500, 750, 1000) and estimating quantities from images.
levels.example_task: This number line is marked at 0 and 1000, with 500 in the middle. An arrow points between 500 and the end. Estimate the number.
levels.example_response: The arrow is about three-quarters of the way between 500 and 1000, so I estimate about 875.
common_errors: Ignoring the benchmarks and guessing (saying 600 for a position close to 900)
Being overly precise (saying exactly 873 rather than giving a sensible estimate like 875 or 900)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Estimating on partially labelled number lines and explaining reasoning using benchmarks, for numbers to 1000.
levels.example_task: A number line shows 200 and 400. An arrow points to a position one-quarter of the way from 200 to 400. What is your estimate? Explain.
levels.example_response: The distance from 200 to 400 is 200. One quarter of 200 is 50. So the arrow is at about 200 + 50 = 250.
common_errors: Ignoring the scale and treating 200-400 as if it were 0-1000
Calculating the quarter incorrectly (saying a quarter of 200 is 100)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading and writing multiples of 100 in words (one hundred, two hundred... nine hundred) and the number 1000.
levels.example_task: Write these numbers in words: 300, 500, 800.
levels.example_response: Three hundred. Five hundred. Eight hundred.
common_errors: Writing 'three hundred' as 'threehundred' (one word)
Spelling errors such as 'hundread' or 'hunderd'

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading and writing three-digit numbers with non-zero tens and ones in words, using a reference chart if needed.
levels.example_task: Write 347 in words.
levels.example_response: Three hundred and forty-seven.
common_errors: Omitting 'and' (writing 'three hundred forty-seven')
Forgetting the hyphen in compound numbers (writing 'forty seven' instead of 'forty-seven')

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reading and writing any three-digit number in words, including those with zeros, without support.
levels.example_task: Write these numbers in words: 604, 210, 999.
levels.example_response: Six hundred and four. Two hundred and ten. Nine hundred and ninety-nine.
common_errors: Writing 604 as 'six hundred and zero four' or 'six hundred and forty'
Confusing teen numbers: writing 'two hundred and eleven' for 210

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Converting between words and numerals in both directions, including interpreting ambiguous or incorrect word forms.
levels.example_task: A pupil wrote 'four hundred and sixty-twelve'. What number did they mean? Write it correctly in words and numerals.
levels.example_response: They probably meant 472 (four hundred and seventy-two). 'Sixty-twelve' is not correct English; the correct way is 'seventy-two' because 60 + 12 = 72.
common_errors: Not recognising the error in the word form
Writing 4612 by combining the numbers literally

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Adding ones, tens or hundreds to a three-digit number using Dienes blocks where no carrying is required.
levels.example_task: Use Dienes blocks to work out 342 + 5.
levels.example_response: Add 5 ones cubes to the 2 ones already there. 342 + 5 = 347.
common_errors: Adding the 5 to the tens column instead (342 + 5 = 392)
Changing the hundreds digit instead (342 + 5 = 842)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Mentally adding ones, tens or hundreds to three-digit numbers, including some carrying cases, with a number line available.
levels.example_task: Work out 356 + 40 mentally.
levels.example_response: 356 + 40 = 396. I added 4 tens to the 5 tens, giving 9 tens.
common_errors: Adding to the wrong column: 356 + 40 = 360 (adding 4 to ones)
Forgetting to carry: 356 + 70 = 3126 instead of 426

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Mentally adding ones, tens or hundreds to any three-digit number, including carrying across place value boundaries, without support.
levels.example_task: Work out 487 + 6 and 487 + 30 mentally.
levels.example_response: 487 + 6 = 493. 7 + 6 = 13, so ones become 3 and carry 1 ten. 487 + 30 = 517. 80 + 30 = 110, so tens become 1 and carry 1 hundred.
common_errors: Forgetting to carry: 487 + 6 = 4813 (concatenating 48 and 13)
487 + 30 = 490 (adding 3 instead of 30)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Subtracting ones, tens or hundreds from a three-digit number using Dienes blocks where no exchanging is required.
levels.example_task: Use Dienes blocks to work out 487 - 5.
levels.example_response: Remove 5 ones cubes. 487 - 5 = 482.
common_errors: Subtracting from the wrong column: 487 - 5 = 437 (subtracting 5 tens)
Counting the remaining cubes incorrectly

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Mentally subtracting ones, tens or hundreds, including some exchange cases, using a number line if needed.
levels.example_task: Work out 534 - 60 mentally. You may use a number line.
levels.example_response: 534 - 60 = 474. I subtracted 6 tens: 53 tens - 6 tens = 47 tens.
common_errors: 534 - 60 = 530 (subtracting 4 instead of 60)
534 - 60 = 574 (subtracting from hundreds then adding back incorrectly)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Mentally subtracting ones, tens or hundreds from any three-digit number, including exchange across boundaries, without support.
levels.example_task: Work out 352 - 7 and 600 - 40 mentally.
levels.example_response: 352 - 7 = 345. I can't take 7 from 2, so I take 7 from 12 (borrowing a ten) to get 5, and 5 tens become 4 tens. 600 - 40 = 560. I need to borrow from the hundreds: 60 tens - 4 tens = 56 tens = 560.
common_errors: 352 - 7 = 355 (subtracting smaller from larger: 7 - 2 = 5)
600 - 40 = 200 (subtracting 400 instead of 40)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Choosing the most efficient mental strategy for a given subtraction and explaining the choice.
levels.example_task: Work out 503 - 497 using the most efficient mental method. Explain why you chose it.
levels.example_response: I used counting on (complementary addition) from 497 to 503: 497 + 3 = 500, then 500 + 3 = 503, so the answer is 6. This is more efficient than column subtraction because the numbers are close together.
common_errors: Using a formal written method for numbers very close together, which is slow and error-prone
Getting the counting on wrong: 497 + 3 = 500 + 3 = 503 but saying the difference is 3 instead of 6

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Adding two three-digit numbers using Dienes blocks, physically regrouping 10 ones into 1 ten or 10 tens into 1 hundred.
levels.example_task: Use Dienes blocks to add 145 + 237. Regroup if any column has 10 or more.
levels.example_response: Ones: 5 + 7 = 12, regroup 10 ones as 1 ten, write 2 ones. Tens: 4 + 3 + 1 = 8 tens. Hundreds: 1 + 2 = 3. Answer: 382.
common_errors: Not regrouping (writing 12 in the ones column to get 3712)
Losing the carried ten (writing 372 instead of 382)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Setting out columnar addition on paper with correct alignment, carrying between columns, with a place value grid for support.
levels.example_task: Use columnar addition to calculate 256 + 178.
levels.example_response: Ones: 6 + 8 = 14, write 4 carry 1. Tens: 5 + 7 + 1 = 13, write 3 carry 1. Hundreds: 2 + 1 + 1 = 4. Answer: 434.
common_errors: Forgetting to add the carried digit (getting 424 instead of 434)
Misaligning columns when numbers have different digit counts

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Fluent columnar addition of any two three-digit numbers, including multiple carries, without support.
levels.example_task: Calculate 467 + 385 using columnar addition.
levels.example_response: Ones: 7 + 5 = 12, write 2 carry 1. Tens: 6 + 8 + 1 = 15, write 5 carry 1. Hundreds: 4 + 3 + 1 = 8. Answer: 852.
common_errors: Forgetting the second carry (getting 842 because tens carry is lost)
Adding digits left to right and not carrying (4 + 3 = 7, 6 + 8 = 14, 7 + 5 = 12, giving 71412)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Adding three-digit numbers where the result exceeds 1000, and checking with estimation.
levels.example_task: Calculate 587 + 468. First estimate, then calculate, then check using inverse.
levels.example_response: Estimate: 600 + 500 = 1100. Calculate: 7 + 8 = 15, write 5 carry 1. 8 + 6 + 1 = 15, write 5 carry 1. 5 + 4 + 1 = 10. Answer: 1055. Check: 1055 - 468 = 587. Correct.
common_errors: Not knowing how to handle a four-digit answer
Estimating after calculating instead of before (defeating the purpose)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Subtracting with Dienes blocks, physically exchanging 1 ten for 10 ones when the top digit is smaller.
levels.example_task: Use Dienes blocks to work out 342 - 117. Exchange when needed.
levels.example_response: Ones: 2 - 7, need to exchange 1 ten for 10 ones. Now 12 - 7 = 5. Tens: 3 - 1 = 2. Hundreds: 3 - 1 = 2. Answer: 225.
common_errors: Subtracting smaller from larger without exchanging (getting 235 by computing 7 - 2 = 5)
Exchanging but forgetting to reduce the tens column (getting 325)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Setting out columnar subtraction on paper with exchanges recorded correctly, using a place value grid.
levels.example_task: Use columnar subtraction to calculate 523 - 247.
levels.example_response: Ones: 3 - 7, exchange a ten. 13 - 7 = 6. Tens: 1 - 4 (now 1 ten after exchange), exchange a hundred. 11 - 4 = 7. Hundreds: 4 - 2 = 2. Answer: 276.
common_errors: Forgetting to reduce the tens after exchanging (getting 376)
Attempting 3 - 7 by reversing: 7 - 3 = 4 (getting 284)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Fluent columnar subtraction of any three-digit numbers, including cascading exchanges, without support.
levels.example_task: Calculate 504 - 268 using columnar subtraction.
levels.example_response: Ones: 4 - 8, exchange from tens. But tens = 0, so exchange from hundreds first: 5 hundreds becomes 4 hundreds and 10 tens. Then exchange 1 ten: 9 tens and 14 ones. 14 - 8 = 6. 9 - 6 = 3. 4 - 2 = 2. Answer: 236.
common_errors: Not knowing how to exchange across a zero (getting stuck at 0 tens)
Cascading exchange errors: making 504 into 4 hundreds, 10 tens, 4 ones instead of eventually reaching 4/9/14

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Solving subtractions with multiple zeros and checking using addition; explaining the exchange process.
levels.example_task: Calculate 600 - 347. Check your answer by adding.
levels.example_response: Exchange: 600 = 5 hundreds, 9 tens, 10 ones. 10 - 7 = 3. 9 - 4 = 5. 5 - 3 = 2. Answer: 253. Check: 253 + 347 = 600. Correct.
common_errors: Not cascading the exchange correctly from 600 (trying 6/0/0 and not knowing where to borrow from)
Getting 253 but being unable to explain why 600 becomes 5/9/10

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Estimating the answer to an addition or subtraction by rounding both numbers to the nearest 100.
levels.example_task: Estimate the answer to 312 + 489 by rounding to the nearest hundred.
levels.example_response: 312 rounds to 300. 489 rounds to 500. 300 + 500 = 800. So the answer is about 800.
common_errors: Rounding incorrectly (rounding 489 to 400 instead of 500)
Computing the exact answer instead of estimating

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Estimating before calculating, then comparing the estimate with the exact answer to judge reasonableness.
levels.example_task: Estimate 278 + 345 first, then calculate exactly. Is your answer reasonable?
levels.example_response: Estimate: 300 + 300 = 600. Exact: 278 + 345 = 623. 623 is close to 600, so my answer is reasonable.
common_errors: Estimating after calculating (biased by the answer)
Not comparing the estimate and exact answer

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using inverse operations to check calculations: after adding, subtracting to verify; after subtracting, adding to verify.
levels.example_task: Calculate 453 + 279. Check your answer using the inverse operation.
levels.example_response: 453 + 279 = 732. Check: 732 - 279 = 453. My original number comes back, so the answer is correct.
common_errors: Repeating the original calculation instead of using the inverse
Making an error in the inverse check and not knowing which answer to trust

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using estimation to spot incorrect answers and explain why they must be wrong.
levels.example_task: A pupil says 356 + 278 = 534. Without calculating the exact answer, explain why this must be wrong.
levels.example_response: 356 rounds to 400 and 278 rounds to 300, so the answer should be about 700. 534 is much less than 700, so the answer must be wrong. Also, 356 + 278 must be more than 356 + 200 = 556, and 534 < 556, so it is definitely wrong.
common_errors: Calculating the exact answer instead of using estimation to explain
Not being able to articulate why the estimate proves the answer wrong

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Building the 3 times table using concrete equal groups of 3 objects, and counting totals.
levels.example_task: Make 5 groups of 3 counters. How many counters altogether?
levels.example_response: 3, 6, 9, 12, 15. There are 15 counters. 5 x 3 = 15.
common_errors: Miscounting the groups (counting 4 groups instead of 5)
Counting the total in ones rather than skip counting in 3s

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Recalling 3 times table multiplication facts and beginning to link to division facts, with a multiplication grid for reference.
levels.example_task: What is 3 x 7? What is 21 divided by 3?
common_errors: Confusing 3 x 7 with 3 x 6 (getting 18 instead of 21)
Knowing 3 x 7 but not being able to derive 21 / 3

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Instant recall of all 3 times table facts (up to 3 x 12) in multiplication and division form.
levels.example_task: Answer these quickly: 3 x 9 = ? 36 / 3 = ? 3 x 11 = ?
common_errors: Hesitating on the harder facts (3 x 7, 3 x 8, 3 x 9)
Not knowing that 3 x 12 = 36 (going only to 3 x 10)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using 3 times table facts to derive related facts with larger numbers.
levels.example_task: If 3 x 8 = 24, what is 30 x 8? Explain how you know.
levels.example_response: 30 x 8 = 240. I know 3 x 8 = 24, and 30 is 10 times bigger than 3, so the answer is 10 times bigger: 24 x 10 = 240.
common_errors: Just adding a zero without understanding why (getting the right answer but no reasoning)
Confusing x10 with +10 (saying 30 x 8 = 34)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Building the 4 times table using arrays or equal groups of 4 objects, connecting to doubling the 2 times table.
levels.example_task: Make an array of 4 rows with 6 counters in each row. How many counters altogether?
levels.example_response: 4 x 6 = 24. I can see it is double the 2 x 6 = 12 array: 12 + 12 = 24.
common_errors: Miscounting the array (getting 22 or 26)
Not seeing the connection to the 2 times table

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Recalling 4 times table facts and the corresponding division facts, using doubling from the 2 times table as a strategy.
levels.example_task: What is 4 x 7? Use the doubling method.
levels.example_response: 2 x 7 = 14, then double 14 = 28. So 4 x 7 = 28.
common_errors: Doubling incorrectly (double 14 = 26 instead of 28)
Knowing 4 x 7 = 28 but not deriving 28 / 4 = 7

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Instant recall of all 4 times table facts (up to 4 x 12) in multiplication and division form.
levels.example_task: Answer these quickly: 4 x 8 = ? 48 / 4 = ? 4 x 11 = ?
common_errors: Confusing 4 x 8 = 32 with 4 x 7 = 28 (off by one group of 4)
Not knowing 48 / 4 = 12 even when knowing 4 x 12 = 48

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using the doubling chain (2s, 4s, 8s) to derive facts and explain the multiplicative structure.
levels.example_task: Explain why all multiples of 4 are also multiples of 2. Then use 4 x 9 = 36 to work out 8 x 9.
levels.example_response: All multiples of 4 are multiples of 2 because 4 = 2 x 2, so every group of 4 contains exactly 2 groups of 2. For 8 x 9: double 4 x 9 = double 36 = 72.
common_errors: Stating the rule without explaining it
Doubling 36 incorrectly (getting 62 or 74 instead of 72)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Building the 8 times table by doubling the 4 times table results using concrete materials.
levels.example_task: You know 4 x 5 = 20. Double 20 to find 8 x 5. Use counters to check.
levels.example_response: Double 20 = 40. So 8 x 5 = 40. Checked: 8 groups of 5 counters = 40 counters.
common_errors: Doubling incorrectly (double 20 = 30)
Not connecting the doubling strategy to the concrete groups

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Recalling 8 times table facts using the doubling strategy from the 4 times table, with a multiplication grid for reference.
levels.example_task: What is 8 x 6? Start from 4 x 6.
common_errors: Doubling the tens but not the ones (double 24 = 44 instead of 48)
Confusing 8 x 6 = 48 with 8 x 7 = 56

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Instant recall of all 8 times table facts (up to 8 x 12) in multiplication and division form.
levels.example_task: Answer these quickly: 8 x 7 = ? 72 / 8 = ? 8 x 12 = ?
common_errors: Confusing 8 x 7 = 56 with 7 x 7 = 49 or 6 x 9 = 54
Not being able to recall division facts from multiplication facts

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using repeated halving as the inverse of the doubling chain to divide by 8.
levels.example_task: Work out 96 / 8 using repeated halving. Show your steps.
levels.example_response: 96 / 2 = 48. 48 / 2 = 24. 24 / 2 = 12. So 96 / 8 = 12. I halved three times because 8 = 2 x 2 x 2.
common_errors: Halving only once or twice instead of three times
Making a halving error: half of 96 = 46 instead of 48

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Identifying the doubling relationship between the 2 and 4 times tables using a side-by-side comparison with concrete arrays.
levels.example_task: Write out the 2 times table and the 4 times table up to x5 side by side. What do you notice?
levels.example_response: 2x1=2, 4x1=4. 2x2=4, 4x2=8. 2x3=6, 4x3=12. 2x4=8, 4x4=16. 2x5=10, 4x5=20. Each answer in the 4 times table is double the answer in the 2 times table.
common_errors: Not noticing the doubling pattern
Thinking the 4 times table answers are '2 more' instead of 'double'

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Extending the doubling pattern to include the 8 times table and using it to derive facts.
levels.example_task: 2 x 6 = 12. Use doubling to find 4 x 6 and then 8 x 6.
levels.example_response: 4 x 6 = double 12 = 24. 8 x 6 = double 24 = 48.
common_errors: Doubling 12 to get 22 instead of 24
Stopping after the 4 times table and not continuing to the 8

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Explaining the doubling chain (2s to 4s to 8s) and using halving as the inverse strategy for division by 4 or 8.
levels.example_task: Explain the connection between 2 x 9, 4 x 9 and 8 x 9. Then use halving to work out 72 / 4.
levels.example_response: 2 x 9 = 18. 4 x 9 = double 18 = 36. 8 x 9 = double 36 = 72. Each time we double. To divide by 4, halve twice: 72 / 2 = 36, 36 / 2 = 18. So 72 / 4 = 18.
common_errors: Using the doubling chain for multiplication but not knowing how to reverse it for division
Halving once instead of twice when dividing by 4

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Multiplying a two-digit number by a one-digit number using concrete equal groups or arrays.
levels.example_task: Use counters to find 13 x 3. Make 3 groups of 13.
levels.example_response: 3 groups of 13: 13 + 13 + 13 = 39. Or: 3 groups of 10 = 30, 3 groups of 3 = 9, 30 + 9 = 39.
common_errors: Miscounting the groups (getting 36 or 42)
Multiplying only the ones: 3 x 3 = 9, forgetting the tens

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using the grid method (partitioning) to multiply a two-digit number by a one-digit number.
levels.example_task: Use the grid method to calculate 24 x 3.
levels.example_response: Partition 24 into 20 and 4. Grid: 20 x 3 = 60, 4 x 3 = 12. Total: 60 + 12 = 72.
common_errors: Forgetting to add the partial products (writing 60 and 12 but not combining them)
Multiplying 2 x 3 instead of 20 x 3 (getting 6 + 12 = 18)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using compact short multiplication (vertical layout) for two-digit times one-digit, with carrying.
levels.example_task: Calculate 47 x 3 using short multiplication.
levels.example_response: 7 x 3 = 21, write 1 carry 2. 4 x 3 = 12, plus 2 = 14. Answer: 141.
common_errors: Forgetting to add the carry: 7 x 3 = 21, carry 2, then 4 x 3 = 12 (forgetting +2, writing 121)
Carrying the wrong digit (carrying 1 instead of 2 from 21)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using the distributive law to explain the method and solving multi-step problems.
levels.example_task: Show that 38 x 4 gives the same answer whether you use 30 x 4 + 8 x 4 or 40 x 4 - 2 x 4. Explain why.
levels.example_response: 30 x 4 + 8 x 4 = 120 + 32 = 152. 40 x 4 - 2 x 4 = 160 - 8 = 152. Both give 152 because 38 = 30 + 8 = 40 - 2, and we can split multiplication across addition or subtraction.
common_errors: Not understanding that subtraction can be used (only seeing addition-based partitioning)
Making arithmetic errors in one of the methods and thinking the law does not work

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Understanding 'times as many' using concrete bar models: comparing a single bar with a bar that is a given number of times longer.
levels.example_task: Sam has 3 stickers. Mia has 4 times as many stickers as Sam. Use cubes to show how many Mia has.
levels.example_response: Sam: 3 cubes. Mia: 4 groups of 3 cubes = 12 cubes. Mia has 12 stickers.
common_errors: Adding 4 instead of multiplying by 4 (saying Mia has 7 stickers)
Confusing 'times as many' with 'more than'

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Drawing bar models for scaling problems and writing the corresponding multiplication statement.
levels.example_task: A pencil is 8 cm long. A ruler is 3 times as long. How long is the ruler? Draw a bar model.
levels.example_response: Pencil: one bar of 8. Ruler: three bars of 8 = 3 x 8 = 24 cm.
common_errors: Drawing 3 bars of 3 instead of 3 bars of 8
Writing 8 + 3 = 11 instead of 8 x 3 = 24

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Solving scaling problems in context, identifying the multiplication or division needed, without bar model support.
levels.example_task: A recipe needs 4 eggs. Tom wants to make 3 times as much. How many eggs does he need? If he has 32 eggs, how many times the recipe can he make?
levels.example_response: 3 times as much: 4 x 3 = 12 eggs. With 32 eggs: 32 / 4 = 8 times the recipe.
common_errors: For the first part: 4 + 3 = 7 eggs (adding instead of multiplying)
For the second part: 32 - 4 = 28 (subtracting instead of dividing)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Solving two-step scaling problems and explaining the difference between additive and multiplicative comparison.
levels.example_task: Aisha has 5 marbles. Ben has 4 more marbles than Aisha. Chloe has 4 times as many marbles as Aisha. Who has more, Ben or Chloe? How many more?
levels.example_response: Ben: 5 + 4 = 9 marbles. Chloe: 5 x 4 = 20 marbles. Chloe has more. 20 - 9 = 11 more.
common_errors: Treating both '4 more' and '4 times as many' the same way
Not understanding the distinction between additive and multiplicative comparison

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding all combinations of 2 items from 2 small sets by physically matching concrete objects.
levels.example_task: You have 2 hats (red, blue) and 3 scarves (green, yellow, striped). Match each hat with each scarf. How many different outfits?
levels.example_response: Red hat + green scarf, red hat + yellow scarf, red hat + striped scarf. Blue hat + green scarf, blue hat + yellow scarf, blue hat + striped scarf. 6 outfits.
common_errors: Missing one combination (finding only 5)
Repeating a combination (counting red+green twice)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Systematically listing combinations in a table and beginning to connect the count to multiplication.
levels.example_task: There are 3 flavours of ice cream (vanilla, chocolate, strawberry) and 4 toppings (sprinkles, sauce, flake, nuts). List all possible combinations in a table.
levels.example_response: Table with 3 rows and 4 columns = 12 combinations. 3 x 4 = 12.
common_errors: Listing unsystematically and missing some combinations
Not connecting the table to multiplication (counting one by one instead)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using multiplication to calculate the number of combinations and explaining why multiplication works.
levels.example_task: A cafe offers 4 types of sandwich and 3 types of drink. How many different meal deals (one sandwich and one drink) are there? Explain why you multiply.
levels.example_response: 4 x 3 = 12 meal deals. I multiply because for each of the 4 sandwiches, there are 3 drink choices. So that is 4 lots of 3.
common_errors: Adding instead of multiplying (4 + 3 = 7)
Not being able to explain why multiplication gives the answer

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Solving correspondence problems with three sets or with constraints.
levels.example_task: A school trip offers 2 activities (museum, park), 3 lunch options (packed lunch, cafe, pizza) and 2 transport options (bus, train). How many different trip plans are possible?
levels.example_response: 2 x 3 x 2 = 12 different trip plans. For each activity, there are 3 lunch options, and for each of those, 2 transport options.
common_errors: Only multiplying two of the three sets (2 x 3 = 6)
Adding all the options (2 + 3 + 2 = 7)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Dividing a concrete whole into 10 equal parts to discover tenths using fraction strips or a metre stick.
levels.example_task: Fold a paper strip into 10 equal parts. Colour 1 part. What fraction have you coloured?
levels.example_response: I coloured 1 out of 10 equal parts. That is one tenth, or 1/10.
common_errors: Folding into unequal parts and still calling each piece a tenth
Saying 'one out of ten' but not writing 1/10

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Counting in tenths on a number line and recognising that 10/10 = 1 whole.
levels.example_task: Count in tenths from 0 to 1 on a number line. What is 7/10? Where does it go?
common_errors: Saying that 10/10 is 'ten tenths' but not recognising it equals 1
Placing 7/10 before 5/10 on the number line

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Connecting tenths to division by 10 and counting in tenths beyond 1 whole.
levels.example_task: What is 3 divided by 10? Count in tenths from 8/10 to 14/10.
common_errors: Thinking 3 / 10 = 30 (multiplying instead of dividing)
Not knowing how to count past 10/10 (stopping at 1 whole)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Connecting tenths to measurement contexts and reasoning about their size relative to other fractions.
levels.example_task: A metre stick is divided into 10 equal parts. How long is each part in centimetres? Is 1/10 of a metre greater or less than 1/4 of a metre? Explain.
levels.example_response: Each part is 100 cm / 10 = 10 cm. 1/10 of a metre = 10 cm. 1/4 of a metre = 25 cm. So 1/10 < 1/4 because dividing into more parts makes each part smaller.
common_errors: Saying 1/10 > 1/4 because 10 > 4
Not knowing that 1 metre = 100 cm to complete the calculation

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding unit fractions of sets of objects by equal sharing using concrete manipulatives.
levels.example_task: Find 1/3 of 12 counters by sharing them equally into 3 groups.
levels.example_response: 12 counters shared into 3 groups = 4 counters in each group. 1/3 of 12 = 4.
common_errors: Sharing into unequal groups
Giving the total instead of one group's count

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Finding unit fractions of quantities using division, and placing unit fractions on a fraction wall or number line.
levels.example_task: Find 1/5 of 20. Place 1/5 on a number line between 0 and 1.
levels.example_response: 1/5 of 20 = 20 / 5 = 4. On the number line, 1/5 is between 0 and 1/2, closer to 0.
common_errors: Dividing by the wrong number: 20 / 1 = 20 instead of 20 / 5
Placing 1/5 after 1/2 on the number line (thinking it is a large fraction)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Comparing unit fractions and explaining that larger denominators make smaller parts.
levels.example_task: Put these fractions in order from smallest to largest: 1/2, 1/8, 1/4, 1/3.
levels.example_response: 1/8, 1/4, 1/3, 1/2. The larger the denominator, the smaller the fraction, because you are splitting the whole into more parts.
common_errors: Ordering by denominator size and getting it backwards: 1/2, 1/3, 1/4, 1/8
Not being able to explain why 1/8 < 1/4

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding non-unit fractions of sets using concrete grouping: first finding the unit fraction, then taking multiple groups.
levels.example_task: Find 2/5 of 15 counters. First find 1/5, then take 2 groups.
common_errors: Finding 1/5 correctly but forgetting to multiply by 2 (answering 3 instead of 6)
Dividing by 2 and then by 5 instead of dividing by 5 and multiplying by 2

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Finding non-unit fractions of quantities using the divide-then-multiply strategy, with pictorial fraction bars.
levels.example_task: Find 3/4 of 20. Show this on a fraction bar.
levels.example_response: 1/4 of 20 = 5. 3/4 of 20 = 3 x 5 = 15. On the fraction bar: 20 split into 4 equal parts (5 each), 3 parts shaded = 15.
common_errors: Finding 1/4 of 20 = 5 but then adding 3 instead of multiplying (5 + 3 = 8)
Shading 3 out of 4 parts on the bar but not calculating the total value

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Finding non-unit fractions of quantities abstractly and placing non-unit fractions on a number line.
levels.example_task: Find 5/8 of 40. Where would 5/8 sit on a number line between 0 and 1?
levels.example_response: 1/8 of 40 = 5. 5/8 of 40 = 5 x 5 = 25. On the number line, 5/8 is between 1/2 (4/8) and 3/4 (6/8), just past halfway.
common_errors: Dividing by the numerator instead of the denominator: 40 / 5 = 8, then 8 x 8 = 64
Not being able to place 5/8 relative to 1/2

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Solving problems requiring finding non-unit fractions and reasoning about what fraction remains.
levels.example_task: There are 24 sweets. Priya eats 3/8 of them. How many are left? What fraction is left?
levels.example_response: 3/8 of 24 = 3 x 3 = 9 sweets eaten. 24 - 9 = 15 left. Fraction left: 8/8 - 3/8 = 5/8.
common_errors: Forgetting to subtract from the total
Not knowing that the remaining fraction is 5/8 (complementary fraction)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using fraction walls or folded paper to see that two fractions can represent the same amount.
levels.example_task: Fold a paper strip in half. Now fold it in half again to make quarters. How many quarters equal one half?
levels.example_response: 2 quarters equal 1 half. 1/2 = 2/4.
common_errors: Folding unevenly so the quarters are not equal
Seeing that 2 quarters fill the same space as 1 half but not writing 1/2 = 2/4

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying equivalent fractions from a fraction wall diagram by comparing bar lengths.
levels.example_task: Using a fraction wall, find a fraction equivalent to 1/3.
levels.example_response: 2/6 = 1/3. Two sixths bars line up exactly with one third bar on the fraction wall.
common_errors: Choosing a fraction that is close but not equivalent (e.g. saying 1/4 looks the same as 1/3)
Not understanding that 'equivalent' means exactly the same value

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Generating equivalent fractions by multiplying the numerator and denominator by the same number, and using diagrams to verify.
levels.example_task: Find two fractions equivalent to 2/4. Show one on a diagram.
levels.example_response: 2/4 = 1/2 (dividing both by 2) and 2/4 = 4/8 (multiplying both by 2). Diagram: a bar split into 4 parts with 2 shaded = a bar split into 8 parts with 4 shaded.
common_errors: Multiplying only the numerator or only the denominator (saying 2/4 = 4/4 or 2/4 = 2/8)
Believing that multiplying top and bottom changes the value

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using equivalent fractions to solve problems, including finding missing numerators or denominators.
levels.example_task: 3/? = 6/8. What is the missing denominator? Explain how you know.
levels.example_response: The numerator doubled from 3 to 6, so the denominator must also double. 3/4 = 6/8. The missing denominator is 4.
common_errors: Adding instead of multiplying: saying the denominator went up by 3 so it must be 3 + 3 = 6
Not recognising the multiplicative relationship between numerator and denominator

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Adding same-denominator fractions using a fraction bar: shading additional parts to see the total.
levels.example_task: A bar is divided into 5 equal parts. Shade 2 parts red, then shade 1 more part blue. What fraction is shaded altogether?
levels.example_response: 2/5 + 1/5 = 3/5. Three out of five parts are shaded.
common_errors: Adding numerators and denominators: 2/5 + 1/5 = 3/10
Not understanding that the denominator stays the same

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Adding and subtracting same-denominator fractions using fraction number lines or bars, with answers remaining within one whole.
levels.example_task: Start at 3/7 on a number line. Move forward 2/7. Where do you land? Then subtract 4/7. Where do you land?
common_errors: Adding denominators: 3/7 + 2/7 = 5/14
Moving the wrong direction for subtraction

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Adding and subtracting same-denominator fractions abstractly, explaining that only numerators change.
levels.example_task: Calculate 5/8 + 2/8 and 6/9 - 4/9. Explain why you only add or subtract the numerators.
levels.example_response: 5/8 + 2/8 = 7/8. 6/9 - 4/9 = 2/9. Only the numerators change because the denominator tells us the size of the pieces, which does not change. 5 eighths + 2 eighths = 7 eighths, like 5 apples + 2 apples = 7 apples.
common_errors: Adding both numerators and denominators (5/8 + 2/8 = 7/16)
Being unable to explain why the denominator stays the same

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Comparing unit fractions using a fraction wall to see which piece is larger.
levels.example_task: Look at a fraction wall. Which is bigger, 1/3 or 1/5? How do you know?
levels.example_response: 1/3 is bigger than 1/5. On the fraction wall, the third bar is longer than the fifth bar because splitting into fewer parts makes each part bigger.
common_errors: Saying 1/5 is bigger because 5 > 3
Not using the fraction wall and guessing

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Ordering unit fractions from smallest to largest and comparing fractions with the same denominator.
levels.example_task: Order from smallest to largest: 1/4, 1/2, 1/6, 1/3. Then order: 2/7, 5/7, 1/7, 6/7.
levels.example_response: Unit fractions: 1/6, 1/4, 1/3, 1/2 (larger denominator = smaller fraction). Same denominator: 1/7, 2/7, 5/7, 6/7 (larger numerator = larger fraction).
common_errors: Ordering unit fractions by denominator in the wrong direction (1/2, 1/3, 1/4, 1/6)
Confusing the two rules when switching between unit fractions and same-denominator fractions

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Comparing and ordering fractions with justification, using both the unit fraction rule and same-denominator rule.
levels.example_task: Which is greater, 3/8 or 5/8? Which is greater, 1/3 or 1/8? Explain each answer.
levels.example_response: 5/8 > 3/8 because they have the same denominator and 5 > 3 (more eighths). 1/3 > 1/8 because both are unit fractions and thirds are bigger pieces than eighths (fewer parts = bigger pieces).
common_errors: Applying the unit fraction rule to same-denominator fractions or vice versa
Not providing justification for the comparison

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Comparing fractions that require reasoning beyond the basic rules, using benchmarks like 1/2.
levels.example_task: Without drawing, which is greater: 3/5 or 2/7? Explain your reasoning.
levels.example_response: 3/5 is greater than 1/2 (because 3 is more than half of 5). 2/7 is less than 1/2 (because 2 is less than half of 7). So 3/5 > 2/7.
common_errors: Comparing numerators alone (3 > 2 so 3/5 > 2/7 -- right answer but wrong reasoning)
Comparing denominators alone (7 > 5 so 2/7 must be bigger)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Measuring objects using a ruler (cm and mm) and a set of kitchen scales (g/kg), recording the measurement in the correct unit.
levels.example_task: Measure this pencil to the nearest centimetre. Weigh this bag of rice on the scales.
levels.example_response: The pencil is 14 cm long. The rice weighs 500 g.
common_errors: Not starting from zero on the ruler (measuring from 1 instead of 0)
Reading the wrong scale line on the kitchen scales

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Recording measurements in mixed units and knowing simple equivalences (1 m = 100 cm, 1 kg = 1000 g, 1 l = 1000 ml).
levels.example_task: A table is 1 m and 35 cm long. Write this in centimetres only.
levels.example_response: 1 m 35 cm = 135 cm because 1 m = 100 cm, so 100 + 35 = 135 cm.
common_errors: Writing 1 m 35 cm = 35 cm (ignoring the metres)
Converting incorrectly: 1 m 35 cm = 1035 cm (adding 1000 instead of 100)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Adding and subtracting measurements in mixed units, converting to a single unit first.
levels.example_task: A bag weighs 2 kg 400 g. Another bag weighs 1 kg 750 g. What is their total weight?
common_errors: Adding without converting: 2 kg 400 g + 1 kg 750 g = 3 kg 1150 g (not regrouping the grams)
Forgetting to add the extra kilogram from the grams total

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Solving multi-step measurement problems involving comparison and conversion between units.
levels.example_task: A ribbon is 2 m 30 cm long. I cut off 85 cm. How much is left? Give your answer in metres and centimetres.
common_errors: Subtracting without converting: 2 m 30 cm - 85 cm = 2 m -55 cm (negative centimetres)
Converting back incorrectly: 145 cm = 14 m 5 cm

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Tracing around a shape on squared paper and counting the unit lengths along each side to find the perimeter.
levels.example_task: A rectangle on squared paper is 4 squares long and 2 squares wide. Trace around the outside and count the units.
levels.example_response: Top: 4, Right: 2, Bottom: 4, Left: 2. Perimeter = 4 + 2 + 4 + 2 = 12 units.
common_errors: Counting the squares inside (area) instead of the units around the edge
Forgetting to count one side (getting 4 + 2 + 4 = 10)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Measuring the sides of simple shapes with a ruler and adding the lengths to find the perimeter.
levels.example_task: Measure each side of this triangle with a ruler and find its perimeter.
levels.example_response: Sides: 5 cm, 4 cm, 3 cm. Perimeter = 5 + 4 + 3 = 12 cm.
common_errors: Measuring inaccurately (not aligning the ruler correctly)
Adding only two sides and missing the third

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Calculating the perimeter of rectilinear shapes where some side lengths are given and others must be deduced.
levels.example_task: A rectangle has a length of 8 cm and a width of 3 cm. What is its perimeter?
common_errors: Adding only length + width (8 + 3 = 11 cm) and not doubling
Confusing perimeter with area (8 x 3 = 24)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Finding the perimeter of compound rectilinear shapes (L-shapes) where missing side lengths must be calculated.
levels.example_task: An L-shape has outer dimensions 6 cm by 4 cm, with a 2 cm by 2 cm square cut from one corner. Find the perimeter.
levels.example_response: The L-shape has 6 sides. Working around the outside: 6 + 2 + 4 + 2 + 2 + 4 = 20 cm. The missing sides are 6-2=4 and 4-2=2.
common_errors: Not calculating the missing side lengths correctly
Missing a side when counting around the L-shape

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Adding amounts of money using play coins and notes in a shopkeeper role-play.
levels.example_task: A toy costs 2.35. You have a 2 coin, a 20p coin, a 10p coin and a 5p coin. Do you have enough?
levels.example_response: 2 + 20p + 10p + 5p = 2.35. Yes, that is exactly enough.
common_errors: Not converting pounds and pence correctly (thinking 2 and 35p is 2.035)
Miscounting coins

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Adding and subtracting money amounts using the pounds and p notation, with pictorial support.
levels.example_task: A book costs 3.75. A pen costs 1.50. What is the total cost?
common_errors: Writing 3.75 + 1.50 = 4.125 (treating as decimals without regrouping pence)
Forgetting to carry over 100p as 1

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Calculating change from a given amount using counting up (complementary addition).
levels.example_task: An apple costs 1.37. You pay with a 2 coin. How much change do you get?
levels.example_response: Count up from 1.37: +3p to 1.40, +60p to 2.00. Change = 63p.
common_errors: Subtracting incorrectly: 2.00 - 1.37 = 1.63 (forgetting to borrow)
Giving change as 73p (confusing the pence calculation)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Solving multi-step money problems involving total cost, change, and comparison.
levels.example_task: Jack buys 3 pencils at 45p each and a rubber for 68p. He pays with 5. How much change does he receive?
common_errors: Not converting pence to pounds for the total (getting 135 + 68 = 203 but writing 2.30)
Making errors in the subtraction from 5.00

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Matching Roman numerals I to XII with Hindu-Arabic numerals 1 to 12 using a clock face for reference.
levels.example_task: Look at this clock face. What number does VI represent? What about IX?
levels.example_response: VI = 6. IX = 9.
common_errors: Confusing IV (4) and VI (6)
Reading IX as 11 (thinking I + X = 11)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading the time from a Roman numeral clock face to the nearest 5 minutes.
levels.example_task: The hour hand is between VIII and IX, and the minute hand points to III. What time is it?
levels.example_response: VIII = 8 and III = 15 minutes. The time is 8:15 or quarter past eight.
common_errors: Reading the minute hand position as the number itself (saying 3 minutes instead of 15)
Confusing the hour and minute hands

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reading any time to the nearest minute from an analogue clock with Roman numerals, writing in 12-hour notation.
levels.example_task: The hour hand is just past XI and the minute hand points to the 7th minute mark past VI. What time is it?
levels.example_response: XI = 11. The minute hand is at 30 + 7 = 37 minutes. The time is 11:37.
common_errors: Miscounting the individual minute marks between the 5-minute intervals
Reading XI as 9 (confusion between IX and XI)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Understanding that a.m. means morning and p.m. means afternoon/evening, and identifying times as a.m. or p.m.
levels.example_task: Is 3 o'clock in the afternoon written as 3 a.m. or 3 p.m.? What about 8 o'clock in the morning?
levels.example_response: 3 o'clock in the afternoon is 3 p.m. 8 o'clock in the morning is 8 a.m.
common_errors: Mixing up a.m. and p.m.
Not knowing whether 12 noon is a.m. or p.m.

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Converting simple times between 12-hour and 24-hour format using the rule 'add 12 for p.m.'
levels.example_task: Convert these times to 24-hour format: 2:30 p.m., 9:15 a.m., 6:00 p.m.
common_errors: Not adding 12 for p.m. times (writing 2:30 p.m. as 02:30)
Adding 12 to a.m. times too (writing 9:15 a.m. as 21:15)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Converting fluently between 12-hour and 24-hour notation in both directions, including noon and midnight.
levels.example_task: Convert to 12-hour time: 17:45, 00:30, 12:00. Convert to 24-hour time: 11:50 p.m.
common_errors: Writing 00:30 as 12:30 p.m. (confusing midnight with noon)
Subtracting 12 from times before 13:00 (writing 12:00 as 0:00)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using 24-hour times in context to solve problems, such as reading timetables.
levels.example_task: A bus leaves at 15:45 and arrives at 16:20. How long is the journey? Another bus leaves at 09:50 and takes the same amount of time. When does it arrive?
levels.example_response: 15:45 to 16:20: from 15:45 to 16:00 is 15 minutes, from 16:00 to 16:20 is 20 minutes. Total = 35 minutes. Second bus: 09:50 + 35 minutes = 10:25.
common_errors: Subtracting as if times are normal numbers: 16:20 - 15:45 = 0:75 = 75 minutes
Adding 35 minutes to 09:50 incorrectly (getting 09:85 instead of 10:25)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Comparing the durations of two events by looking at a timeline or counting on from start to end time on a clock.
levels.example_task: Maths starts at 9:00 and finishes at 10:00. PE starts at 1:30 and finishes at 2:15. Which lesson is longer?
levels.example_response: Maths is 1 hour = 60 minutes. PE is 45 minutes. Maths is longer.
common_errors: Saying PE is longer because 2:15 is a bigger number than 10:00
Not knowing that 1 hour = 60 minutes

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Calculating the duration between two times using counting on, where the duration does not cross an hour boundary.
levels.example_task: A film starts at 3:20 and finishes at 3:55. How long is the film?
levels.example_response: From 3:20 to 3:55 = 35 minutes.
common_errors: Subtracting 55 - 20 = 35 (correct here but the method will fail across an hour boundary)
Saying 25 minutes (miscounting the gap)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Calculating durations that cross hour boundaries using the bridging-through-the-hour strategy.
levels.example_task: A journey starts at 2:45 and ends at 4:10. How long is the journey?
levels.example_response: 2:45 to 3:00 = 15 minutes. 3:00 to 4:00 = 60 minutes. 4:00 to 4:10 = 10 minutes. Total = 85 minutes = 1 hour 25 minutes.
common_errors: Treating time as base-10: 4:10 - 2:45 = 1.65 = 1 hour 65 minutes
Forgetting to add all the parts together

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Solving multi-step duration problems involving conversions between seconds, minutes and hours.
levels.example_task: A race takes 2 minutes and 45 seconds. Another race takes 195 seconds. Which race is longer? By how many seconds?
levels.example_response: 2 minutes 45 seconds = 120 + 45 = 165 seconds. 195 seconds is longer. 195 - 165 = 30 seconds longer.
common_errors: Converting 2 minutes as 200 seconds instead of 120 seconds
Saying both races are the same because 2 minutes 45 seconds 'looks like' 245 which is bigger than 195

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Drawing 2-D shapes on squared or dotted paper and making 3-D shapes from construction kits (e.g. Polydron, straws and clay).
levels.example_task: Draw a rectangle with sides 5 cm and 3 cm on squared paper. Build a cube from construction straws.
levels.example_response: Rectangle drawn on squared paper: 5 squares along, 3 squares up, with right angles at each corner. Cube: 12 straws of equal length, 8 clay balls at vertices.
common_errors: Drawing the rectangle without measuring (sides not 5 and 3 squares)
Building a shape that looks like a cube but has unequal edges

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Drawing specified 2-D shapes on plain paper with a ruler, and describing 3-D shapes by their faces, edges and vertices.
levels.example_task: Draw a triangle with sides 4 cm, 5 cm and 6 cm. How many faces, edges and vertices does a triangular prism have?
levels.example_response: Triangle drawn with measured sides. A triangular prism has 5 faces (2 triangles, 3 rectangles), 9 edges and 6 vertices.
common_errors: Drawing the triangle without a ruler or with inaccurate side lengths
Miscounting faces or edges of the prism (saying 3 faces because they only count the rectangular ones)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Drawing shapes to precise specifications including right angles (using a set-square) and describing 3-D shapes in different orientations.
levels.example_task: Draw a rectangle 6 cm by 2 cm. Then draw a right-angled triangle with the two shorter sides 3 cm and 4 cm.
levels.example_response: Rectangle: 6 cm and 2 cm sides, verified with ruler, right angles checked with set-square. Right-angled triangle: 3 cm and 4 cm sides meeting at a right angle, verified with set-square.
common_errors: Not using a set-square to check right angles
Drawing the right-angled triangle with the wrong angle as the right angle

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Experiencing angles as turns through physical movement: making quarter, half, three-quarter and full turns.
levels.example_task: Stand up and face the door. Make a quarter turn clockwise. What are you facing now?
levels.example_response: After a quarter turn clockwise from the door, I am facing the window (90 degrees of turn).
common_errors: Making a half turn instead of a quarter turn
Turning the wrong direction (anticlockwise instead of clockwise)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying angles in shapes and connecting them to turns, using a paper corner as a right-angle tester.
levels.example_task: How many angles does a triangle have? Test each corner of this rectangle with a paper corner. Are they right angles?
levels.example_response: A triangle has 3 angles. The rectangle has 4 corners, and each one matches the paper corner exactly, so they are all right angles.
common_errors: Thinking the number of angles equals the number of sides only for some shapes
Saying a shape has no angles because the corners look 'smooth'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Connecting fraction turns to right angles: quarter turn = 1 right angle, half turn = 2 right angles, three-quarter turn = 3 right angles, full turn = 4 right angles.
levels.example_task: How many right angles in a half turn? How many right angles in a full turn? If you face north and make three right-angle turns clockwise, which direction do you face?
levels.example_response: Half turn = 2 right angles. Full turn = 4 right angles. Three right-angle turns clockwise from north: north to east to south to west. I face west.
common_errors: Saying a full turn is 2 right angles (confusing with half turn)
Getting confused about the direction after multiple turns

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using a folded paper right-angle tester to find right angles in the classroom environment.
levels.example_task: Fold a piece of paper to make a right angle. Find 5 right angles in the classroom.
levels.example_response: Corner of a book, corner of the whiteboard, corner of the window frame, corner of a desk, corner of a door.
common_errors: Folding the paper inaccurately so the tester is not a true right angle
Identifying acute or obtuse angles as right angles without testing

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Classifying angles as right, acute or obtuse by comparing them to a right-angle tester.
levels.example_task: Look at these three angles. Use your right-angle tester to classify each as right, acute or obtuse.
levels.example_response: Angle A is smaller than my right angle tester: acute. Angle B matches exactly: right angle. Angle C is bigger than my tester: obtuse.
common_errors: Confusing acute and obtuse (saying a big angle is acute)
Thinking the length of the lines affects the angle size

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Identifying and classifying angles in 2-D shapes without a tester, and connecting right angles to turns.
levels.example_task: How many right angles are in a square? A regular pentagon has no right angles. Are its angles acute or obtuse?
levels.example_response: A square has 4 right angles. A regular pentagon's angles are all obtuse (each is bigger than a right angle but less than a straight line).
common_errors: Saying a square has 2 right angles (only counting top corners)
Thinking all angles in regular shapes are right angles

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Reasoning about angles in shapes and using the relationship between right angles and turns.
levels.example_task: A shape has exactly 2 right angles and 2 obtuse angles. Can you name what it might be? Explain.
levels.example_response: A trapezium can have 2 right angles and 2 obtuse angles. It is a right trapezium: the two right angles are where one vertical side meets the parallel sides, and the other two angles are obtuse.
common_errors: Drawing a shape where the angles do not add up correctly
Not being able to visualise a shape with a mix of angle types

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Identifying horizontal and vertical lines in the classroom environment using concrete references (spirit level, plumb line).
levels.example_task: Point to something horizontal in the classroom. Now point to something vertical.
levels.example_response: The floor is horizontal. The wall is vertical.
common_errors: Confusing horizontal and vertical (saying the wall is horizontal)
Thinking diagonal lines are either horizontal or vertical

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Identifying parallel and perpendicular lines in shapes and the environment, using a set-square to verify.
levels.example_task: Look at this rectangle. Which sides are parallel? Which sides are perpendicular?
levels.example_response: The top and bottom sides are parallel (same distance apart, never meet). The top and left side are perpendicular (they meet at a right angle). There are 2 pairs of parallel sides and 4 pairs of perpendicular sides.
common_errors: Confusing parallel and perpendicular
Saying only opposite sides can be perpendicular (not seeing adjacent sides meeting at right angles)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Identifying horizontal, vertical, parallel and perpendicular lines in diagrams and shapes, using correct vocabulary.
levels.example_task: Draw a pair of parallel lines. Draw a pair of perpendicular lines. In a triangle, can you have a pair of parallel sides?
levels.example_response: Parallel lines drawn with arrows showing they never meet. Perpendicular lines drawn meeting at a right angle with the square symbol. A triangle cannot have parallel sides because all three sides meet at vertices.
common_errors: Drawing lines that look parallel but converge when extended
Forgetting the right-angle symbol for perpendicular lines

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Analysing shapes by counting pairs of parallel and perpendicular sides, and reasoning about line relationships.
levels.example_task: How many pairs of parallel sides does a regular hexagon have? Explain.
levels.example_response: A regular hexagon has 3 pairs of parallel sides. Each side is parallel to the side directly opposite it. There are 6 sides total, giving 3 opposite pairs.
common_errors: Saying 6 pairs (confusing sides with pairs)
Not recognising that non-adjacent sides can be parallel

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading a pictogram where each symbol represents 1 item, and reading a bar chart with a scale of 1.
levels.example_task: This pictogram shows favourite fruits. Each apple symbol = 1 child. How many children chose banana?
levels.example_response: There are 5 banana symbols, so 5 children chose banana.
common_errors: Miscounting the symbols
Not reading the key before interpreting the pictogram

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading a pictogram where each symbol represents 2 items, including interpreting half-symbols, and reading bar charts with a scale of 2 or 5.
levels.example_task: In this pictogram, each star symbol = 2 votes. The row for 'Pizza' shows 4 full stars and a half star. How many votes for Pizza?
levels.example_response: 4 full stars = 4 x 2 = 8 votes. Half star = 1 vote. Total = 9 votes.
common_errors: Counting the symbols as the value (saying 4.5 votes instead of 9)
Ignoring the half-symbol (saying 8 votes)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reading and interpreting scaled bar charts and pictograms where each unit represents 5 or 10, and presenting data in a bar chart with a chosen scale.
levels.example_task: A bar chart shows the number of books read. The scale goes up in 5s. The bar for 'March' reaches to the line between 15 and 20. How many books were read in March?
levels.example_response: The bar is halfway between 15 and 20. Halfway between 15 and 20 is 17 or 18. Looking carefully, it appears to be at the midpoint, so about 17 or 18 books.
common_errors: Reading the value as exactly 15 or 20 (not noticing the bar is between the lines)
Not being able to determine values between scale markings

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Choosing an appropriate scale for data and creating a bar chart or pictogram, justifying the scale choice.
levels.example_task: These are the results of a survey: Red 35, Blue 20, Green 15, Yellow 30. Draw a bar chart. What scale will you use? Why?
levels.example_response: I will use a scale of 5 because all the values are multiples of 5, which makes the bars easy to draw accurately. The y-axis goes from 0 to 35 in steps of 5.
common_errors: Choosing a scale of 1 (making the chart unnecessarily tall for values up to 35)
Choosing a scale of 10 and being unable to plot 15 or 35 accurately

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Answering one-step questions by reading a single value directly from a bar chart, pictogram or table.
levels.example_task: A bar chart shows favourite colours. How many children chose blue?
levels.example_response: The bar for blue reaches 12 on the scale. 12 children chose blue.
common_errors: Reading the wrong bar
Misreading the scale (saying 10 when the bar is at 12)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Answering 'how many more' or 'how many fewer' questions that require reading two values and subtracting.
levels.example_task: The bar chart shows: Football 25, Swimming 15, Tennis 10. How many more children chose football than tennis?
levels.example_response: Football: 25. Tennis: 10. 25 - 10 = 15. Fifteen more children chose football.
common_errors: Adding instead of subtracting (25 + 10 = 35)
Reading the correct values but choosing the wrong operation

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Solving two-step questions from data, such as finding a total and then comparing, or combining categories before answering.
levels.example_task: A table shows pets: Dogs 18, Cats 12, Fish 8, Rabbits 7. How many more children have dogs or cats than fish or rabbits?
levels.example_response: Dogs + Cats = 18 + 12 = 30. Fish + Rabbits = 8 + 7 = 15. Difference: 30 - 15 = 15 more.
common_errors: Only completing the first step (saying 30 and 15 but not finding the difference)
Comparing only one pair instead of the combined categories

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Interpreting data to answer reasoning and explanation questions, including 'is it true that...' and 'explain why'.
levels.example_task: A pictogram shows: Monday 20, Tuesday 15, Wednesday 25, Thursday 10, Friday 30. A pupil says 'More than half the total ice creams were sold on Wednesday and Friday.' Is this true? Show your working.
levels.example_response: Total = 20 + 15 + 25 + 10 + 30 = 100. Wednesday + Friday = 25 + 30 = 55. Half of 100 = 50. 55 > 50, so yes, more than half were sold on Wednesday and Friday.
common_errors: Not calculating the total first
Finding half of the wrong number (half of 55 instead of half of 100)
